instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power

This mac went through another assistance, where <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was missing and the tracks 17,18,19,20,21,22,23 and 24 of this component were missing, I remade the tracks and put the component <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, I checked the connectivity. 

Voltage:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.60V; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.32V; <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0.3 , no pulse; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v, no pulse; <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.37v; <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V;

Coils:
L7130 8.60/8.73V
L7520 0v, no pulse
L7560 0v, no pulse
L7430 0V, pulseless
L7630 0V, no pulse
L7310 0V
L7320 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Post diode mode at L7520/60.
If charger has been connected without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, one of <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/60 could be fried now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
L7520 0. 448V
L7560 0.375V.
Replaces <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/60 and made another jumper on the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> mesh that had no connection.solved on the L7560 3.33V coil, the L7520 coil is missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
These are the output voltages of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, are they correct ? 
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> 3.33V; <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.61V; <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> 3.31V; <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> 3.31V; <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_SKIPSEL</SIGNAL> 2V; <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_CSP2</SIGNAL> 3.33V; <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.38V; 3.33V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: As you get now <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, check <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> presence, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.33v; <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.05V; <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V; 

COILS: L7560 3.33V; L7430 0V and L7630 0V, without pulse ; L7310/20 0V; 

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> all pins are with 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V"
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL>.
If OK, there can be a problem with SMC.
Try to reflow it, and reball if no result.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"Verifique <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> "
I see that tomorrow.
I performed the SMC reball, without success.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> 3.35V.
L7630 0v, pulso 130mA;
L7430 0v, pulso 110mA;
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> 0v;<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0v; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0.13V; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.34V; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> 0.14V
I already did the SMC reball.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
No idea how can you catch mA puls on a coil  :eek:.

If <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is OK and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is low, then bad SMC; PCH can also pull down the signal, because of some internal problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: started to cool the cooler, but after I reballed the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> the cooler stopped spinning and the voltages in the coils were missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Re-check your job.
Let <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> out of board; is not really needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> is heating up, replacing but without results.
Can you tell me the input and output voltages of u74/7600  ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Which voltages do you get now on the board?
Any short on big coils?
